posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: We only have CIM, RS775, and NEOs in our team; we want to renew our motors this year. What do you think we should prefer? What are the advantages and disadvantages?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: Especially, can you make more posts like this? I don’t know anything about motors, but I’d love more 1v1 matches featuring robot parts. I’m a big fan of the graphic!

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: On paper at least, the difference is pretty clear.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: I can come up with more content like this before the season when we are missing a lot of parts.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: Yes, I have examined them, but I think more torque will generate more power from the battery, and we can attach the vortex directly to the shaft, there are numerous different combinations for the intake or shooter. We are genuinely curious about how more experienced teams utilize it effectively.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: The Kraken exhibits superior performance compared to others, equipped with an integrated motor controller. Further comparisons of size are needed between the Kraken and the Vortex, including its control hat addition.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/2/f/2f93dd4191c11975bc33d69a4beb03797910066f.gif

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: I think you’re comparing the wrong things here. I’d recommend choosing either the Kraken x60 or the NEO Vortex, rather than the Kraken x44. The x60 is basically the same price as the x44 but fits more easily into the FRC FIRST Robotics Competition COTS Commercial off-the-shelf ecosystem with its 2" bolt circle. We’ve used both Kraken and Vortexes. Both work fine in most applications. Wouldn’t recommend Vortexes in the SDS Swerve Drive Specialties Mk4i swerve modules. We also still use NEOs and I don’t think you’re going to see huge gains in performance by upgrading from those.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Vortex at Stall: ~58.6 Amps / 1 N-m Torque
Kraken X44 at Stall: ~67.9 Amps / 1 N-m Torque
Kraken X60: ~51.6 Amps / 1 N-m Torque at stall

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: We will definitely buy the Kraken X60 this season. We discussed among ourselves that these engines perform better in intake and shooter tasks. According to your suggestion, would it be better to use X60 in shooter and intake?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: At least as far as efficiency goes, there are other factors to consider beyond efficiency, such as weight, desired RPM, necessary gearing (which impacts weight), and space. On our robot this year, we primarily used Kraken X60s but also employed two NEO 550s in positions requiring low speed and high torque. Utilizing a planetary gearbox with a larger reduction on NEO 550s was easier and lighter than applying a smaller reduction on Kraken X60s in specific cases. Essentially, when reducing a motor, especially needing a particular ratio, choosing a smaller motor and applying a greater reduction tends to be more straightforward and efficient.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: Using neo550 / neo with planetary gearbox represents a superior choice compared to vortex or x44. Our inventory includes both neo and planetary gearboxes, allowing us to incorporate neo550 into our lineup for scenarios requiring this configuration. Initially overlooked due to its low torque performance, we recently reconsidered thanks to new insights.

posts.name: Garrison
posts.cooked: The main benefit of the X44 is its smaller form factor and reduced weight compared to the X60. While it may not provide substantial competitive advantages for many FRC teams, including my own, the X60 has functioned well for two years. As the COTS ecosystem continues to develop and incorporates this motor, the benefits of the X44 over the X60 are likely to become more pronounced.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
In specific scenarios, yes, though it's also prudent to consider that CTRE released their Minion brushless motor recently, akin to the NEO550, yet possibly without the latter's drawbacks. WCP has suggested a potential upcoming gearbox solution from West Coast Products, which might affect the current calculations regarding motor selection.

Our team has maintained NEO550s in limited inventory over the past few years despite primarily using Falcons500s or Kraken X60s, but could explore using a mix of Kraken X44s and Minions based on upcoming products. If WCP introduces a native gearbox compatible with these new motors, we'd likely lean towards adopting that system, eliminating the need for REV/VEX setups.

link_counts.title: Minion - A standalone brushless motor with versatile mounting – CTR Electronics

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Torque of the motor isn’t important because you’ll always add a gearbox. A 6000rpm motor provides 20% less torque per amp than a 5000rpm motor. Gearing it down to 5000rpm makes the motors have the same torque per amp and free speed. However, higher RPM motors may require additional gearing for the same output torque, though minor differences typically don’t matter. Instead, focus on peak power and efficiency since they influence power loss (as heat) even at low currents. For instance, gear-down a Vortex or NEO550 to match a Kraken X60, and the X60 generates less heat for the same output torque. Larger motors also have more thermal mass, reducing burnout risks. In general, opt for larger motors if space allows, as smaller ones offer minimal benefits—they sacrifice performance and increase heat generation and thermal issues. Once experienced, reconsider smaller motors.

One subtler difference I would pay attention to is the details other than the motor specifications.

A pro and con of CTRE (Krakis) is that they have a very good software ecosystem. It is much more robust regarding complex control requests—for instance, it can handle PID loops on the controller without needing to run them yourself on the ROBOIO—compared to other brands. Additionally, if you use swerve drive, they provide a simple way to generate the code for the whole drive subsystem. You can also get extra features using the CANivore, though this restricts you to using only CTRE CAN-FD components (though this option is still available).

From an electronics standpoint, my team has used Sparkmaxes and Neos in the past and encountered numerous issues with strange CAN behavior and controllers failing. While these problems may stem from our skills, CTRE motors haven't experienced any issues. In general, SparkFlex also had several problems (such as grounding issues to the housing) compared to CTRE motors, which only had minor issues like excessive current limits that were promptly resolved via a firmware update for the Kraken X60 series.

For prototyping, REV products require less of a complete electronics setup—they mainly need power—and can operate with just the accompanying apps to update firmware. However, CTRE products demand everything to function properly. Moreover, the CTRE app offers an easier time assigning device IDs and maintaining consistency when picking up devices.

In summary, when choosing between brands, consider not just motor stats but also the accompanying APIs, apps, and long-term reliability.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: According to all you've said, using Kraken seems more advantageous in terms of motor specs, software, and API performance.

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: Can we use Neo and Spark Max while using Carnivore? By connecting it to the CAN bus line in RoboRIO, of course.

Sorry for not making that clear; of course you can. One more thing that I forgot to mention is that it is also an advantage of using a CANivore that you have an additional CAN loop that can fail separately without destroying the other CAN loop (i.e., segregate the two vendors for two different loops).

posts.name: Esat
posts.cooked: If we buy Kraken, it will be very advantageous to use it as a carnivore.
